abstract: A pledge by Merck to invest $1.5 billion in research and development in China suggests that the pharmaceutical industry’s center of gravity is shifting eastward.
snippet: A pledge by Merck to invest $1.5 billion in research and development in China suggests that the pharmaceutical industry’s center of gravity is shifting eastward.
lead_paragraph: Drug research tends to follow spending. Take Merck’s pledge on Tuesday to invest $1.5 billion in research and development in China over five years. Citizens of emerging economies are growing wealthier and living longer, while the fiscal health of their governments is robust. Merck’s step suggests that the pharmaceutical industry’s center of gravity is shifting eastward accordingly.

byline.original: By Robert Cyran and George Hay

abstract: Advertisers are bullish on video, networks are anxious about the NFL and Mitt Romney changes his mind about Fox News.
snippet: Advertisers are bullish on video, networks are anxious about the NFL and Mitt Romney changes his mind about Fox News.
lead_paragraph: One of the takeaways from the annual UBS global media and communications conference in Midtown Manhattan, Stuart Elliott and Amy Chozick report, is the primacy of video content “regardless of the type of screen on which it is watched.” Based on the talks there, “marketers remain keen on buying commercial time during video programming despite the uncertain outlook for the economy.” Spending on TV ads around the world next year will increase 6.7 percent from 2011, said one forecaster, Vincent Létang, as compared with a predicted overall 5 percent increase in advertising. (Online ads will have the greatest growth, he predicted, 11.2 percent.)

abstract: Chinese regulators have approved Nestlé’s $1.7 billion acquisition of a 60 percent stake in the confectioner Hsu Fu Chi International, in a sign that Beijing may be warming to large cross-border transactions.
snippet: Chinese regulators have approved Nestlé’s $1.7 billion acquisition of a 60 percent stake in the confectioner Hsu Fu Chi International, in a sign that Beijing may be warming to large cross-border transactions.
lead_paragraph: Chinese regulators have approved Nestlé’s $1.7 billion acquisition of a 60 percent stake in the confectioner Hsu Fu Chi International, in a sign that Beijing may be warming to large cross-border transactions.

headline.main: China Clears Nestle’s Deal for Candy Maker

abstract: A Chinese court rejected Apple’s claim to own the iPad trademark in China, which could stifle sales of the popular tablet in some Chinese cities. Apple has been butting heads with Proview Technology, which made an unsuccessful attempt to sell a tablet computer called I-Pad.
snippet: A Chinese court rejected Apple’s claim to own the iPad trademark in China, which could stifle sales of the popular tablet in some Chinese cities. Apple has been butting heads with Proview Technology, which made an unsuccessful attempt to sell a ta...
lead_paragraph: 3:58 p.m. | Updated  Adding quote from lawyer at end.

headline.main: IPad Faces Trademark Trouble in China

abstract: The Times’s correspondent in Shanghai will answer selected questions from readers about China’s economy and business climate.
snippet: The Times’s correspondent in Shanghai will answer selected questions from readers about China’s economy and business climate.
lead_paragraph: David Barboza has been a correspondent for The New York Times based in Shanghai, China, since November 2004. In a series of recent articles, he has examined China’s system of government-managed capitalism in depth. He will be answering questions from readers in connection with these articles. Submit your question via the comments section below. Mr. Barboza will respond to a selection of questions in the days ahead.

headline.main: Ask David Barboza About China’s Economy
